title: cymo880
author: cymo880
content: Cross-chain interoperability has become a critical feature in the blockchain ecosystem. However, the current solutions, such as bridges, often come with high fees, security concerns, and inefficiencies that deter users from engaging in cross-chain transactions. I’d like to share an idea for a novel approach to cross-chain token exchanges and invite feedback, improvements, or potential collaboration on its implementation.The idea is to develop a smart contract-based protocol with the following characteristics; Native Smart Contracts on Each BlockchainThe protocol would deploy smart contracts on all supported blockchains.These contracts would act as escrow mechanisms for tokens during the exchange process. Peer-to-Peer Exchange MechanismInstead of relying on liquidity pools, the protocol would facilitate peer-to-peer exchanges.Two parties looking to swap tokens across different blockchains can interact directly through the protocol.Each party sends their tokens to the protocol's smart contract on their respective blockchain. Cross-Chain Validation and AtomicityThe protocol ensures that both transactions are valid and completed before releasing tokens.If one transaction fails, the entire exchange is rolled back, maintaining an atomic swap principle. Minimal FeesFees would be limited to basic transaction costs for interacting with the smart contracts

comments.author: nelson4lov
comments.body: Looks like your thread is mostly focused on altcoin chains since these are the ones that have to do with bridging (for now).Move it to altcoin discussion.__________________________________________Your idea isn't too bad, only problem is that it is already implemented on most existing bridges and they still aren't perfect. For instance, wrapped bitcoin. Btw, as long as it's a smart contract, there's always going to be attack surfaces.
